Your videos were a distraction for people from their everyday life. The depth of the content was of no importance. It was all just fun. No need to feel embarrassed about those old videos of yours. You feel like those videos are shallow with no substance but if anything, people loved them. Entertainment is all what people expect from a PewDiePie video and it is a great accomplishment that you have been bringing joy to so many people for so many years. Now, I believe this is the time for you to quit YouTube. With utmost respect for your long career that I have enjoyed being a spectator of (I wished to say 'part of' as in part of bro army, but that is corny af), I have nothing to state here but facts. Your content feels empty and low effort now more than ever. Uninspiring is the word, no disrespect intended. Continuing to post the stuff that you have been posting will dilute the channel that you have built. By dilute, I mean adding more characterless and bland videos and bringing down the quality of your channel. I would say, "Making the channel less epic". You can either continue uploading. The views are there. The reddit has gone to shit but you reacting to them somehow makes them entertaining. Nothing is stopping you from uploading. Or you can quit now and abandon this channel as an antique in the internet museum. Like Papa Franku did. Or there is another possible route that you can take. Start another channel. My name recommendation, "PewDieVlogs". Upload all your cool vlogs there. Vsauce Michael does that. I feel like I've grown up with Felix and his content changes somehow reflected on my life at the time. Back when I was a teenager I enjoyed those really loud videos where something crazy was always happening because they distracted me from the struggles we all go through at that age. Now, having become more of an adult I enjoy these slow paced videos. I no longer need to fill my head with a bunch of exciting things because I find the simple things of life just so much fulfilling. I also notice I don't need an upload from Felix everyday, cause I have work and I keep myself busy. Getting a video from him from time to time is like catching up with an old friend. You don't need to spend every living moment with them as when you were younger, but you love them and appreciate them just as much.

This is such a great video, and really challenges the unfortunate notion of our culture and how we view success.  Everyone is part of this rat race, and we don‚Äôt get to have quality moments - everything is more shallow. And it‚Äôs reflected in Felix‚Äôs videos - the gaming era was about having fun, he was able to shine his personality through, it‚Äôs low pressure. The meme review era was shallower, since there‚Äôs more pressure to produce quantity over quality - it‚Äôs not as fun anymore, but you can‚Äôt step back now. And now Felix is in such a beautiful part of his life where he‚Äôs been able to go through the ups and downs, and come to terms what success truly means to him. Being able to do activities we love, sharing our lives in quality ways with our closest friends and family, having opportunities to adventure and great experiences.   These recent videos have been so heartwarming, so humbling, and inspiring. You don‚Äôt always need to be on top to feel like you‚Äôre on top.

Thank you for sharing your reflection. I'm lucky to watch it at the beginning of my YT journey.   I started because of wanting to help adults develop their skills better. When starting, I thought if I can help just one person to learn better or end in a better place in life (like I did thanks to my education and skills), then I'll be happy.   But once you upload your first video, analytics kick in, strangers approach you to increase your SEO, improve your thumbnails, etc, and the numbers game is on. If I already see it now, I can't even imagine the extent of this you must have experienced with millions of subscribers and a decade of work.   Growing is nice and feels encouraging, but it's easy to forget the real motivation behind it. Your video reminds me to protect that, so thank you. :)

Felix? I am glad that I have gotten to grow up with you. I was in some dark places in my life when I found you. After I saw your videos, it helped me to get through what I was going through. I remember when you said you were doing Youtube because you had felt lonely. I felt that. My mom even saw you in an online article about how you started getting paid to play video games, and she ended up changing her mind about me playing video games. She really hated it before and really tried to prevent me from playing them, which sucked because it was a coping mechanism and I met most of my friends playing online. I wanted to do Youtube for the same reason you started. I've been watching you for 4 years now, and I will say that I'm very sad that you don't upload as much as you used to. But I think I can speak for a lot of people when I say that honestly the things you used to upload like Meme Review or Pew News weren't interesting in and of themselves--*you* are what made those fun to watch. I always really liked your insight into the stupid petty drama, and being that I was at the age where I started to form my own morals and such, your insight really resonated with me and it helped me grow as a person. I really relate to you as a person, and coming from a small bigoted town, it really helped me become more comfortable with myself because I could watch your videos and see that I wasn't alone in my way of thinking. You really inspired me to make YouTube my career, and I've now picked colleges and majors in order to fulfill my dream, largely because of you. Your variety of videos also really inspired me because I know that we (the die hard fans I guess you could say) watch your videos for you. You just have a really great presence and vibe that makes people feel uplifted, and I hope to have that same effect on my viewers one day. Hell, you even inspired me to actually read philosophy instead of just wanting to--I actually took the steps necessary to get involved with it because I watched your Book Reviews and wanted to be able to get something meaningful from it like you had. Overall, I'm just really glad you're still here. Your videos have really meant a lot to me over the years, and helped me in ways I didn't think they could. That being said, I hope you continue to do what makes you happy--even if that means no more videos.

That was over 10 years ago. I don't even know those buddies anymore, we haven't talked in years. I felt i couldn't relate to him anymore. So i stopped following.  At times, i used to check in to see how he's doing, but never stayed.  Then in 2020, i was already going through a lot of changes in the beginning of the year and then came covid. I had been watching much more YouTube than usually and started to find my self watching pewdiepie and getting the same feeling as back in the first 5 years, except that felix has "grown up" and learned from his mistakes. Jenna Marbles doing whatever she wanted was what really propelled her forward before she left. Honestly, it becomes really clear when someone is enjoying the videos they make. Relaxed content absolutely has it's place. People change and grow and their interests and focuses shift and it's interesting to see.  If people aren't here for that, that's fine too. Not everything is for everyone.  I've seen a few youtubers when they aren't worried about the money associated anymore just do whatever they want and just enjoy sharing with others. The parasocial relationship becomes more like a good friend of the family rather than an obsession over a specific person and it's cool to see, and honestly, I think healthier for both creator and viewer alike.

First Pewdiepie video I've watched in a while. It sounds to me like you've officially gone through the whole cycle of life experienced in many things, including YouTube. You start just for funzies and to see where it may go; you start peaking where you're pumping out things for all to see; you eventually reach the peak of your powers where there really isn't much else to do; a new life for you begins. We've all experienced or will experience such a thing someday. I think it's good that you've acknowledged this not so much to us, but to yourself. I most definitely understand the occasional thoughts of retirement, as in what else is there to do? What other worlds are there to conquer? At the same time, it's great that you choose to stick with YT, since that's always been your dream. But now that you've pretty much reached the peak of your fame with little else to do, there's nothing better to do now then to go back to where it all started: doing what you love for funzies. I'm glad I grew up with this channel, this wonderful community and the man himself, Felix. It's been heck of a run from taking on barrels to taking on governments or the mass media or platforms or the inner selves of every individual, this community has always been together. We laughed together, played together and above all grew up together. With every up and down just like how Felix grew up to be a better version of himself, we/I too came to know how to be a better person myself. For that I sincerely thank you, Felix. Thanks for all those wonderful times, thanks for helping me grow up, although we didn't know each other, your content helped me to be the "me" today. I don't know how it's possible but perhaps it's the small things that leave the biggest impacts.  And tbh, I expected this ride to be over way earlier. I thought he'd quit years ago and just like every good thing, this journey of joy will also come to an end. And even if he continued there was no assurance that I'd continue to watch his videos given that people change. But that's the thing, he's still here and I'm too. Cause just like me, he too grew up along with his contents. To many people, their childhood hero/idol doesn't retain the title years after they grow up but in my case the guy I admired as a kid is still one of the guys I admire as a person the most.   Now this channel is at a phase which I can relate to as a person the most, the laid back atmosphere, the random videos, everything just exudes serenity. But I still know that this too will surely come to an end. And I know for sure that I won't be upset then cause I know how to cherish every moment of my life and so I'm cherishing every moment with this channel as well. So, finally when the time comes, I hope he and I, we're both at a better place at life where we're both comfortable in our respective places.  So, again thanks, Felix. Thanks for everything.

YouTube is a very weird thing now and days. Everyone is doing it, whether it's to do it just to do it, or do it because they just like creating stuff. Me personally I just love making videos. I'd love to be able to make this a job, even if it's the bare minimum. As long as I'd be able to pay bills, buy food, and occasionally be able to treat myself with a game here and there. I'd be 100% ok with it. I love this. The problem is the chances of me being able to do this and survive off of it is 0 to none. Because I can't edit well, my thumbnails are very meh. I've been doing this for roughly 2 years, and seen little to no results. I've been stuck at 80 for the last year and it's why I took like a 8 month hiatus. I was demotivated to hell. And it kinda sucked. Lately I've been trying to get back into it. And I now have 2 weeks worth of videos to go up till the first. And I'm actually having fun again making videos. Will It pay off? Probably not but ya never know

Building housing complexes for the elderly, getting grants from US Agencies to do this, so grandma can afford to stay in the community near her kids but not have to live with them, and families that need subsidized housing because there are jobs that pay well, but rents are so high where I live that these people need help!

I don't usually leave comments, or in general, express my opinion online. However, the difference between me, a guy who sees himself as funny and witty or whatever, and you, a guy who is funny and witty or whatever, in posting videos online is the underlying desire and want to do so. Do your viewers see the "youtube hussle" as an expression of themselves, do they want to share their life in the same way you do? Sure some do. Did other ones starter their journey for goals other than that - money, fame, freedom from the confines of "regular" employment? Sure. All of those are valid, all of the aforementioned are cool. For you to at this point in your career realize the your place in this weird space is nothing more than what you wished for at the beginning is great, it shows that despite the numbers and the opportunities granted to you, the fame, the fortune Youtube was your passion. So keep doing what you like, and most importantly - have fun!

You just want to keep in touch with your community.  Later down the road, whenever you have your own child, you could pass down the torch to your child, let them have a go at this stuff just for fun, not on the same level as you did with daily uploads, but to use it as a means to interact with your community/followers. There's probably good things to learn from that, and well, bad things too.  I appreciate many types of content on youtube, sure, people grow attached to specific things but they usually come out of their shells and enjoy other things. I used to watch you for your oldschool reactions while playing scary games, that was the reason i subbed to you ages ago. That did not stop me from accepting other types of content eventually. I used to hate vlogs when i was younger, but now i like them. Things change, like you did, along with change comes growing up, which is something a lot of people commenting probably still need to achieve. So don't take those opinions for granted and let them impact on what you should do or not. You do what you like, that is what matters, you will always have people watching, even if you keep going untill you reach retirement age, you will still have a fanbase watching, bigger or smaller does not matter, what matters is the impact. Yours is not bad, despite whatever drama comes your way. We live in a world where negative aspects seem to be ruling stronger than ever.

Hi Felix, I've been following you since the Amnesia days. At that time I was a prepubescent 13 year old kid living in Italy and finding out there was a funny guy that plays good videogames which I couldn't afford to play or that weren't in Italy yet. I learned english through you, and it was quite funny looking at english teachers getting freaked out on how I learned english so fast(and so wrong lol). In high school you've been my role model and moral support in the toughest occasions, and later on you became almost a moral guide and pushed me back into reading books and getting into philosophy a bit more. It's been a continuos journey of laughs, cries and self improvement. Although you influenced me a lot, my passion was always animals and their behavior, and I now moved to Sweden to continue studying what I love. I just want to thank you for letting me realize throughout these years how to be truly happy, you were one of the factors that led me to what I am today and I think I'm living now the best version of myself.

Some people don't understand the reality about "quitting": you never quit something, you eventually do it less and less until it dies down, or revives someday when you decide to do it again. It doesn't matter, for example, how hellbent World of Warcraft players are about quitting. You never quit something entirely. It's like life. Do you quit life? No. You keep living until life eventually ends.

You have all these really energized videos that overdoes it on the editing, which results in the feeling that there‚Äôs no break. If you do videos for fun and not fame, naturally you‚Äôre true self will come out, and you‚Äôre not gonna burn yourself out by flexing cash, raising your voice, or obsessing with due dates and schedules. Because there‚Äôs no ‚Äúfun‚Äù for the YouTuber and/or audience, it‚Äôs all gonna get old real fast.

I'll always be here for the support, love you and Marzia, please, keep posting for as long as you feel like it, it'll be a truly sad day when/if you ever decide to stop.

Since YouTube removed the dislike button, I‚Äôve been using the view-to-like ratio to access the feedback on videos. Usually a 10 to 1 ratio is regarded as excellent (e.g 1000 views, 100 likes).  As at the time of this comment, this video has about 330k views and 130k. That‚Äôs roughly a 3:1 view-like ratio. Super impressive üëè
